title: Cavenham Heath Walking Route

images.title: Stuart Shepherd / Cavenham Heath  National Nature Reserve
images.caption: Cavenham Heath National Nature Reserve. The 'entrance' to Natural England's NNR on The Icknield Way Path - this section strictly speaking is in Tuddenham Heath.

images.title: Bob Jones / Entry to Cavenham Heath National Nature Reserve
images.caption: Entry to the reserve. Access to this area of woodland is permitted at all times, although other open areas of heathland are subject to restricted access.

images.title: Cavenham church and houses by John Goldsmith, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Cavenham church and houses

images.title: Pill box, Cavenham Heath by Hugh Venables, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Pill box on the heath.

images.title: Bob Jones / River Lark west of Icklingham
images.caption: River Lark west of Icklingham. Looking downstream before Temple Bridge. You'll find this picturesque  scene on the eastern side of the heath.

images.title: Stuart Shepherd / Through the Birch
images.caption: Through the Birch. Looking up from the footpath to open heathland and the fire-beater stand.

description: Enjoy a short stroll around this pretty nature reserve near Bury St Edmunds . The site includes heathland, riverside meadows, woodland, wet woodland scrub and small areas of fen. There's lots of wildlife to look out for including a good population of Britain's only poisonous snake, the adder. You can park at Temple Bridge to start your walk which follows part of the Icknield Way Path . Near to the reserve you can also pick up the Lark Valley Path and enjoy a riverside stroll along the River Lark. You could follow it west into the attractive market town of Mildenhall . Also nearby is King's Forest and the popular West Stow Country Park . On the southern side of the park there's also Lackford Lakes where there's a free car park, cafe and visitor centre. Birds visiting the lakes include kingfisher, great crested grebe and tufted duck.
